Meta.ShortDescription: A type of hematoma, usually associated with traumatic brain injury. Blood gathers between the inner layer of the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. Usually resulting from tears in bridging veins which cross the subdural space, subdural hemorrhages may cause an increase in intracranial pressure (ICP), which can cause compression of and damage to delicate brain tissue.

Symptoms.Symptom: Loss of consciousness or fluctuating levels of consciousness
Inability to speak or slurred speech
Deviated gaze, or abnormal movement of the eyes.

Causes.Cause: Head injury in which rapidly changing velocities may stretch and tear small bridging veins.
Shearing injuries due to rotational or linear forces.
A classic symptom of shaken baby syndrome
Anticoagulants or antiplatelet drugs like warfarin and aspirin

RiskFactors.RiskFactor: Elederly and alcoholics who have evidence of cerebral atrophy
Use of anticoagulant or antiplatelet drugs like warfarin and aspirin
Very young or very old age

Diagnostics.Diagnostic: Classic crescent shape on a CT scan, with concave surface away from the skull.

Treatments.Treatment: Depends upon size and rate of growth
Some small hematomas can be managed by monitoring until the body heals itself
Insert small catheter through a hole drilled through the skull and sucking out the hematoma
Large hematomas require craniotomy, the surgical opening of the skull.

Prognoses.Prognosis: Subdural hematomas are often life-threatening when acute. Chronic subdural hematomas, however, have a better prognosis if properly managed.
